title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to his captain.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: any more than the gods themselves are the authors of evil. The youth who
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Enough of gods and heroes;--what shall we say about men? What the poets

author: Plato

text: and story-tellers say--that the wicked prosper and the righteous are
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: The subjects of poetry have been sufficiently treated; next follows
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: style. Now all poetry is a narrative of events past, present, or to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: come; and narrative is of three kinds, the simple, the imitative, and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: a composition of the two. An instance will make my meaning clear.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: The first scene in Homer is of the last or mixed kind, being partly
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: description and partly dialogue. But if you throw the dialogue into the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: assented, but Agamemnon was wroth, and so on--The whole then becomes
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: descriptive, and the poet is the only speaker left; or, if you omit the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: narrative, the whole becomes dialogue. These are the three styles--which
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and comedy are to be admitted?' Yes, but also something more--Is it not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: doubtful whether our guardians are to be imitators at all? Or rather,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: has not the question been already answered, for we have decided that one
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: tragedy and comedy, or be rhapsodist and actor at once? Human nature
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: is coined into very small pieces, and as our guardians have their own
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: business already, which is the care of freedom, they will have enough
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to do without imitating. If they imitate they should imitate, not any
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: meanness or baseness, but the good only; for the mask which the actor
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: wears is apt to become his face. We cannot allow men to play the parts
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of women, quarrelling, weeping, scolding, or boasting against the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: gods,--least of all when making love or in labour. They must not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: represent slaves, or bullies, or cowards, drunkards, or madmen, or
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: blacksmiths, or neighing horses, or bellowing bulls, or sounding rivers,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: or a raging sea. A good or wise man will be willing to perform good and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: wise actions, but he will be ashamed to play an inferior part which he
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: has never practised; and he will prefer to employ the descriptive style
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: with as little imitation as possible. The man who has no self-respect,
title: The Republic

text: on the contrary, will imitate anybody and anything; sounds of nature
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and cries of animals alike; his whole performance will be imitation of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: gesture and voice. Now in the descriptive style there are few changes,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: but in the dramatic there are a great many. Poets and musicians use
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: either, or a compound of both, and this compound is very attractive
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to youth and their teachers as well as to the vulgar. But our State in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: which one man plays one part only is not adapted for complexity. And
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: State; we prefer the rough, honest poet, and will not depart from our
title: The Republic

text: original models (Laws).
title: The Republic

text: Next as to the music. A song or ode has three parts,--the subject, the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: first. As we banished strains of lamentation, so we may now banish the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: one expressive of courage, the other of obedience or instruction or
title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: than any of them. The lyre and the harp may be permitted in the town,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and the Pan's-pipe in the fields. Thus we have made a purgation of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: which he arranges so as to equalize the syllables with one another,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: assigning to each the proper quantity. We only venture to affirm the
title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: metre to the style; and that the simplicity and harmony of the soul
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: anywhere, from the creative and constructive arts, as well as from the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: forms of plants and animals.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Other artists as well as poets should be warned against meanness or
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: life and experience. There is a music of the soul which answers to the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: harmony of the world; and the fairest object of a musical soul is the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: fair mind in the fair body. Some defect in the latter may be excused,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: but not in the former. True love is the daughter of temperance, and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: temperance is utterly opposed to the madness of bodily pleasure. Enough
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: has been said of music, which makes a fair ending with love.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Next we pass on to gymnastics; about which I would remark, that the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: soul is related to the body as a cause to an effect, and therefore if we
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: educate the mind we may leave the education of the body in her charge,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and need only give a general outline of the course to be pursued. In
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the first place the guardians must abstain from strong drink, for they
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: should be the last persons to lose their wits. Whether the habits of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: meat only, and gives them no fish although they are living at the
title: The Republic

text: sea-side, nor boiled meats which involve an apparatus of pots and pans;
title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: forbidden. Where gluttony and intemperance prevail the town quickly
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: airs as soon as the freemen of a State take an interest in them. But
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: what can show a more disgraceful state of education than to have to go
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: abroad for justice because you have none of your own at home? And yet
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: there IS a worse stage of the same disease--when men have learned
title: The Republic

text: to take a pleasure and pride in the twists and turns of the law; not
title: The Republic

text: considering how much better it would be for them so to order their lives
title: The Republic

text: as to have no need of a nodding justice. And there is a like disgrace in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: employing a physician, not for the cure of wounds or epidemic disorders,
title: The Republic

text: but because a man has by laziness and luxury contracted diseases

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: practice of medicine. Eurypylus after he has been wounded drinks a
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: posset of Pramnian wine, which is of a heating nature; and yet the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: sons of Asclepius blame neither the damsel who gives him the drink, nor
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Patroclus who is attending on him. The truth is that this modern system
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of nursing diseases was introduced by Herodicus the trainer; who,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: being of a sickly constitution, by a compound of training and medicine
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: tortured first himself and then a good many other people, and lived
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: a great deal longer than he had any right. But Asclepius would not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: practise this art, because he knew that the citizens of a well-ordered
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: State have no leisure to be ill, and therefore he adopted the 'kill
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: or cure' method, which artisans and labourers employ. 'They must be
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: at their business,' they say, 'and have no time for coddling: if they

author: Plato

text: recover, well; if they don't, there is an end of them.' Whereas the rich
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: man is supposed to be a gentleman who can afford to be ill. Do you know
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: consistent with that practice of virtue which Phocylides inculcates?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: When a student imagines that philosophy gives him a headache, he never
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: and his sons practised no such art. They were acting in the interest of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the public, and did not wish to preserve useless lives, or raise up a
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: puny offspring to wretched sires. Honest diseases they honestly cured;
title: The Republic

text: and if a man was wounded, they applied the proper remedies, and then let

author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: professions. The physician should have had experience of disease in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the judge controls mind by mind; and therefore his mind should not be
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: corrupted by crime. Where then is he to gain experience? How is he to be
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: evil-doers, because he has no pattern of evil in himself; and therefore
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the ideal of a judge; the criminal turned detective is wonderfully
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: suspicious, but when in company with good men who have experience, he is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: at fault, for he foolishly imagines that every one is as bad as himself.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Vice may be known of virtue, but cannot know virtue. This is the sort of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: medicine and this the sort of law which will prevail in our State; they
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: will be healing arts to better natures; but the evil body will be left
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to die by the one, and the evil soul will be put to death by the other.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: And the need of either will be greatly diminished by good music which
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: health to the body. Not that this division of music and gymnastic really
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: corresponds to soul and body; for they are both equally concerned with
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the soul, which is tamed by the one and aroused and sustained by the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: other. The two together supply our guardians with their twofold nature.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: The passionate disposition when it has too much gymnastic is hardened
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and brutalized, the gentle or philosophic temper which has too much
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: water through the funnel of his ears, the edge of his soul gradually
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: wears away, and the passionate or spirited element is melted out of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: him. Too little spirit is easily exhausted; too much quickly passes into
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: his courage doubled, but he soon grows stupid; he is like a wild beast,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: ready to do everything by blows and nothing by counsel or policy. There
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: are two principles in man, reason and passion, and to these, not to the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: soul and body, the two arts of music and gymnastic correspond. He who
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: mingles them in harmonious concord is the true musician,--he shall be
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the presiding genius of our State.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: The next question is, Who are to be our rulers? First, the elder must
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: rule the younger; and the best of the elders will be the best guardians.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Now they will be the best who love their subjects most, and think that
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: they have a common interest with them in the welfare of the state. These
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: we must select; but they must be watched at every epoch of life to see
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: whether they have retained the same opinions and held out against force
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and enchantment. For time and persuasion and the love of pleasure may
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: enchant a man into a change of purpose, and the force of grief and pain
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: may compel him. And therefore our guardians must be men who have been
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: passed first through danger, then through pleasure, and at every age
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: have come out of such trials victorious and without stain, in full
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: in harmonious exercise for their country's good. These shall receive the
title: The Republic

text: 1. Plato's account of pleasure is remarkable for moderation, and in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: this respect contrasts with the later Platonists and the views which are
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: attributed to them by Aristotle. He is not, like the Cynics, opposed
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to all pleasure, but rather desires that the several parts of the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: soul shall have their natural satisfaction; he even agrees with the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Epicureans in describing pleasure as something more than the absence of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: pain. This is proved by the circumstance that there are pleasures which
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: have no antecedent pains (as he also remarks in the Philebus), such as
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the pleasures of smell, and also the pleasures of hope and anticipation.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: In the previous book he had made the distinction between necessary
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and unnecessary pleasure, which is repeated by Aristotle, and he now
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: observes that there are a further class of 'wild beast' pleasures,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: corresponding to Aristotle's (Greek). He dwells upon the relative and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: unreal character of sensual pleasures and the illusion which arises out
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of the contrast of pleasure and pain, pointing out the superiority of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the pleasures of reason, which are at rest, over the fleeting pleasures
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of sense and emotion. The pre-eminence of royal pleasure is shown by
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the fact that reason is able to form a judgment of the lower pleasures,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: while the two lower parts of the soul are incapable of judging the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: pleasures of reason. Thus, in his treatment of pleasure, as in many
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: other subjects, the philosophy of Plato is 'sawn up into quantities' by
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Aristotle; the analysis which was originally made by him became in the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: next generation the foundation of further technical distinctions. Both
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: in Plato and Aristotle we note the illusion under which the ancients
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: fell of regarding the transience of pleasure as a proof of its
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: unreality, and of confounding the permanence of the intellectual
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: pleasures with the unchangeableness of the knowledge from which they are
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: derived. Neither do we like to admit that the pleasures of knowledge,
title: The Republic

text: though more elevating, are not more lasting than other pleasures,
title: The Republic

text: and are almost equally dependent on the accidents of our bodily state
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: of Plato. Though unable to give a complete answer to them, we may
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: which is contained in them.
title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of the tragic drama, and in him Plato saw the friend and apologist of

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: branch of Greek literature, was falling under the power of rhetoric.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: his own age. Nor can he have been expected to look with favour on the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: Eccleziazusae, or Female Parliament (Laws).

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: nature, for 'one man in his life' cannot 'play many parts;' the
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: and to leave nothing which can be truly called himself. Neither can any
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: 7. Human life and conduct are affected by ideals in the same way that
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: they are affected by the examples of eminent men. Neither the one nor
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the other are immediately applicable to practice, but there is a virtue
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: flowing from them which tends to raise individuals above the common
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: routine of society or trade, and to elevate States above the mere
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: interests of commerce or the necessities of self-defence. Like the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: ideals of art they are partly framed by the omission of particulars;
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: they require to be viewed at a certain distance, and are apt to fade
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: away if we attempt to approach them. They gain an imaginary distinctness
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: when embodied in a State or in a system of philosophy, but they still
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: remain the visions of 'a world unrealized.' More striking and obvious to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the ordinary mind are the examples of great men, who have served their
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: own generation and are remembered in another. Even in our own family
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: circle there may have been some one, a woman, or even a child, in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: whose face has shone forth a goodness more than human. The ideal then
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: approaches nearer to us, and we fondly cling to it. The ideal of the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: past, whether of our own past lives or of former states of society, has
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: a singular fascination for the minds of many. Too late we learn that
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: such ideals cannot be recalled, though the recollection of them may
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: have a humanizing influence on other times. But the abstractions of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: philosophy are to most persons cold and vacant; they give light without
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: warmth; they are like the full moon in the heavens when there are no
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: stars appearing. Men cannot live by thought alone; the world of sense is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: always breaking in upon them. They are for the most part confined to a
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: corner of earth, and see but a little way beyond their own home or place
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of abode; they 'do not lift up their eyes to the hills'; they are not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: awake when the dawn appears. But in Plato we have reached a height from
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: which a man may look into the distance and behold the future of the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: world and of philosophy. The ideal of the State and of the life of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the philosopher; the ideal of an education continuing through life and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: extending equally to both sexes; the ideal of the unity and correlation
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of knowledge; the faith in good and immortality--are the vacant forms of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: light on which Plato is seeking to fix the eye of mankind.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: 8. Two other ideals, which never appeared above the horizon in Greek
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Philosophy, float before the minds of men in our own day: one seen more
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: clearly than formerly, as though each year and each generation brought
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: us nearer to some great change; the other almost in the same degree
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: retiring from view behind the laws of nature, as if oppressed by them,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: but still remaining a silent hope of we know not what hidden in the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: heart of man. The first ideal is the future of the human race in this
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: world; the second the future of the individual in another. The first is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the more perfect realization of our own present life; the second,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the abnegation of it: the one, limited by experience, the other,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: transcending it. Both of them have been and are powerful motives of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: action; there are a few in whom they have taken the place of all earthly
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: interests. The hope of a future for the human race at first sight seems
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: to be the more disinterested, the hope of individual existence the more
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: egotistical, of the two motives. But when men have learned to resolve
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: their hope of a future either for themselves or for the world into the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: will of God--'not my will but Thine,' the difference between them falls
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: away; and they may be allowed to make either of them the basis of their
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: lives, according to their own individual character or temperament. There
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: is as much faith in the willingness to work for an unseen future in this
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: world as in another. Neither is it inconceivable that some rare nature
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: may feel his duty to another generation, or to another century, almost
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: as strongly as to his own, or that living always in the presence of God,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: he may realize another world as vividly as he does this.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: BOOK I.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: I went down yesterday to the Piraeus with Glaucon the son of Ariston,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: that I might offer up my prayers to the goddess (Bendis, the Thracian
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Artemis.); and also because I wanted to see in what manner they would
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: celebrate the festival, which was a new thing. I was delighted with the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: procession of the inhabitants; but that of the Thracians was equally,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: if not more, beautiful. When we had finished our prayers and viewed the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: spectacle, we turned in the direction of the city; and at that instant
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Polemarchus the son of Cephalus chanced to catch sight of us from a
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: distance as we were starting on our way home, and told his servant to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: run and bid us wait for him. The servant took hold of me by the cloak
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: behind, and said: Polemarchus desires you to wait.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: I turned round, and asked him where his master was.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: There he is, said the youth, coming after you, if you will only wait.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Certainly we will, said Glaucon; and in a few minutes Polemarchus
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: appeared, and with him Adeimantus, Glaucon's brother, Niceratus the son
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of Nicias, and several others who had been at the procession.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Polemarchus said to me: I perceive, Socrates, that you and your
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: companion are already on your way to the city.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: You are not far wrong, I said.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: But do you see, he rejoined, how many we are?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Of course.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: And are you stronger than all these? for if not, you will have to remain
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: where you are.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: May there not be the alternative, I said, that we may persuade you to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: let us go?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: But can you persuade us, if we refuse to listen to you? he said.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Certainly not, replied Glaucon.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Then we are not going to listen; of that you may be assured.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Adeimantus added: Has no one told you of the torch-race on horseback in
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: honour of the goddess which will take place in the evening?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: With horses! I replied: That is a novelty. Will horsemen carry torches
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and pass them one to another during the race?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Yes, said Polemarchus, and not only so, but a festival will be
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: celebrated at night, which you certainly ought to see. Let us rise soon
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: after supper and see this festival; there will be a gathering of young
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: men, and we will have a good talk. Stay then, and do not be perverse.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Glaucon said: I suppose, since you insist, that we must.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Very good, I replied.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Accordingly we went with Polemarchus to his house; and there we found
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: his brothers Lysias and Euthydemus, and with them Thrasymachus the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Chalcedonian, Charmantides the Paeanian, and Cleitophon the son of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Aristonymus. There too was Cephalus the father of Polemarchus, whom I
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: had not seen for a long time, and I thought him very much aged. He was
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: seated on a cushioned chair, and had a garland on his head, for he had
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: been sacrificing in the court; and there were some other chairs in the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: room arranged in a semicircle, upon which we sat down by him. He saluted
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: me eagerly, and then he said:--
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: You don't come to see me, Socrates, as often as you ought: If I were
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: still able to go and see you I would not ask you to come to me. But
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: at my age I can hardly get to the city, and therefore you should come
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: oftener to the Piraeus. For let me tell you, that the more the pleasures
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of the body fade away, the greater to me is the pleasure and charm
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of conversation. Do not then deny my request, but make our house your
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: resort and keep company with these young men; we are old friends, and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: you will be quite at home with us.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: I replied: There is nothing which for my part I like better, Cephalus,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: than conversing with aged men; for I regard them as travellers who
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: have gone a journey which I too may have to go, and of whom I ought to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: enquire, whether the way is smooth and easy, or rugged and difficult.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: And this is a question which I should like to ask of you who have
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: arrived at that time which the poets call the 'threshold of old age'--Is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: life harder towards the end, or what report do you give of it?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: I will tell you, Socrates, he said, what my own feeling is. Men of my
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: age flock together; we are birds of a feather, as the old proverb says;
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and at our meetings the tale of my acquaintance commonly is--I cannot
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: eat, I cannot drink; the pleasures of youth and love are fled away:
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: there was a good time once, but now that is gone, and life is no longer
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: life. Some complain of the slights which are put upon them by relations,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and they will tell you sadly of how many evils their old age is the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: cause. But to me, Socrates, these complainers seem to blame that which
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: is not really in fault. For if old age were the cause, I too being old,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and every other old man, would have felt as they do. But this is not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: my own experience, nor that of others whom I have known. How well I
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: remember the aged poet Sophocles, when in answer to the question, How
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: does love suit with age, Sophocles,--are you still the man you were?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Peace, he replied; most gladly have I escaped the thing of which you
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: speak; I feel as if I had escaped from a mad and furious master. His
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: words have often occurred to my mind since, and they seem as good to
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: me now as at the time when he uttered them. For certainly old age has
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: a great sense of calm and freedom; when the passions relax their hold,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: then, as Sophocles says, we are freed from the grasp not of one mad
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: master only, but of many. The truth is, Socrates, that these regrets,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: and also the complaints about relations, are to be attributed to the
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: same cause, which is not old age, but men's characters and tempers; for
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: he who is of a calm and happy nature will hardly feel the pressure of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: age, but to him who is of an opposite disposition youth and age are
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: equally a burden.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: I listened in admiration, and wanting to draw him out, that he might go
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: on--Yes, Cephalus, I said: but I rather suspect that people in general
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: are not convinced by you when you speak thus; they think that old
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: age sits lightly upon you, not because of your happy disposition, but
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: because you are rich, and wealth is well known to be a great comforter.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: You are right, he replied; they are not convinced: and there is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: something in what they say; not, however, so much as they imagine. I
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: might answer them as Themistocles answered the Seriphian who was abusing
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: him and saying that he was famous, not for his own merits but because he
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: was an Athenian: 'If you had been a native of my country or I of yours,
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: neither of us would have been famous.' And to those who are not rich and
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: poor man old age cannot be a light burden, nor can a bad rich man ever
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: have peace with himself.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: May I ask, Cephalus, whether your fortune was for the most part
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: inherited or acquired by you?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: of making money I have been midway between my father and grandfather:
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: his patrimony, that which he inherited being much what I possess now;
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: but my father Lysanias reduced the property below what it is at present:
title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: who have inherited their fortunes than of those who have acquired them;
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the makers of fortunes have a second love of money as a creation of
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: they are very bad company, for they can talk about nothing but the
title: The Republic

text: praises of wealth.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: That is true, he said.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: Yes, that is very true, but may I ask another question?--What do you
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: consider to be the greatest blessing which you have reaped from your
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: wealth?
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: One, he said, of which I could not expect easily to convince others.
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: For let me tell you, Socrates, that when a man thinks himself to be near
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: the tales of a world below and the punishment which is exacted there
title: The Republic

title: The Republic

author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: journey;--hope which is mightiest to sway the restless soul of man.'
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: How admirable are his words! And the great blessing of riches, I do not
title: The Republic
author: Plato

text: say to every man, but to a good man, is, that he has had no occasion to

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

text: Well said, Cephalus, I replied; but as concerning justice, what is
title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic

title: The Republic
author: Plato

title: The Republic

text: his condition.
title: The Republic
